image.altText: A toddler strapped into a pram.

items.synopsis: Quentin Corrigan, who is charged with the murder of 17-month-old toddler Ronan Davies, has appeared in court for the first time. He has been remanded in custody.

title.children: Man charged with murder of 17-month-old toddler Ronan Davies faces court

image.altText: A man with black short hair and glasses

items.synopsis: Women who were secretly filmed by breast surgeon Ho Keun Shin tell an Adelaide court of the impact his crimes have has had on their lives, with one saying he has impacted her "ability to breastfeed my child without fear of being violated again".

title.children: 'Shocked, humiliated, angry': Breast surgeon's indecent filming victims describe violation

image.altText: A low beige brick building with a sign at the front

items.synopsis: A 74-year-old man from South Australia's south-east has been sentenced to at least four and a half years' jail for sexually abusing his young granddaughter after admitting the crime on a camera set up by her parents.

title.children: Man jailed after being caught on nanny-cam admitting to sexual abuse of granddaughter

image.altText: Linda Burney wearing white shirt and purple glasses standing in front a podium with a blue background

items.synopsis: Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney names four priorities for the proposed Voice to Parliament in a speech to the National Press Club, after growing pressure to detail how it would benefit First Nations people.

title.children: Linda Burney says there is everything to gain and nothing to lose by supporting the Voice

image.altText: A smiling woman with white hair.

items.synopsis: NSW Police Senior Constable Kristian White appears in court via video link charged with tasering 95-year-old dementia patient Clare Nowland, who died days later.

title.children: Magistrate 'disgusted' with prosecutors as police officer charged with tasering 95yo faces court via video link

image.altText: Thunderbirds players hug each other with smiles on their faces

items.synopsis: After years of neglect, the South Australian government is expected to announce significant investment in Netball SA Stadium, a move spurred on by the Adelaide Thunderbirds' first grand final appearance since 2013.

title.children: Thunderbirds set to be rewarded with stadium upgrade after securing Super Netball grand final berth

image.altText: A screen that says "Artificial Intelligence" and "ChatGPT" above a keyboard. A silver statuette is in the foreground.

items.synopsis: Education Minister Blair Boyer says it is essential that students learn to use AI safely before they graduate. The trial is set to run for two months, after which a decision about a broader rollout will be made.

title.children: ChatGPT-style app to be trialled in schools to teach AI safety

image.altText: A woman with brown curly hair in a business suit standing outside a grey building with columns

items.synopsis: South Australia's parliament still has a "toxic" culture of bullying and harassment, according to SA Best MLC Connie Bonaros, despite a raft of changes designed to overhaul the workplace.

title.children: 'I have people reaching out to me for help': Female MP says culture of SA parliament still 'toxic'

image.altText: A woman wearing pink pulling gym equipment

items.synopsis: A world-first study from Australian researchers has found the likely reason why breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy commonly experience reduced cognitive function.

title.children: Deirdre's brain fog was so bad she forgot what day it was. Scientists now know why

image.altText: A crowd of men and women stand looking serious, Littleproud and Price at the fore.

items.synopsis: Senior members of the Nationals are locking in behind David Littleproud amid leadership chatter, adding they're "not worried at all".

title.children: Senior Nationals dismiss leadership speculation as 'rubbish'

image.altText: woman standing looking down barrel holding baby boy, she has brown hair and is wearing glasses, baby has big blue eyes

items.synopsis: Home owners are struggling with increasing repayments amid reports that regional house prices have stagnated, despite interest rates staying on hold on Tuesday.

title.children: 'We've gone backwards': Young family sells home because they can't afford repayments, interest rate pause no help

image.altText: An old grainy photo of a smiling young woman with dark hair, a blue top and silver necklace, her hand held up to her right ear.

items.synopsis: WA Police reveal a male DNA profile has been found in their renewed investigation into the murder of the 22-year-old more than four decades ago.

title.children: 'Male DNA found': Police make breakthrough in search for Perth cold-case killer

image.altText: Children are escorted to safety by their rescuers

items.synopsis: Police say 16 children in the Philippines have been "removed from harm" by local authorities after a major, international child protection investigation.

title.children: Airport luggage search in Australia leads to the rescue of 16 children from alleged sexual abuse overseas

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and bright blue glasses looks over the shoulder of a police officer sitting at an office desk

items.synopsis: The visit to the Joint Emergency Services Communications Centre came as part of coronial inquests into the domestic violence deaths of four Indigenous women in the Northern Territory.

title.children: '135 jobs to be dispatched': NT coroner spends a night at the emergency call centre

image.altText: A screenshot from the Barbie trailer showing Margot Robbie in front of a crudely drawn world map.

items.synopsis: Maps can be very touchy subjects. That's why Vietnam has banned the Barbie movie, writes Donald Rothwell.

title.children: Barbie's world map makes no sense, but even it can cause an international incident

image.altText: A close up of a smiling woman wearing a traditional dress on a Bhutanese square.

items.synopsis: After centuries of isolation, Bhutan opened its doors to tourism in the 1970s. But when the ABC was granted rare entry into the country, it found a nation losing a high proportion of people — mainly to Australia.

title.children: 'It feels so empty': The forbidden kingdom of Bhutan is turning into a ghost town

image.altText: A serious-looking Chinese woman in a blue suit stands at a podium and gestures with her hand.

items.synopsis: Australian citizen and legal scholar Kevin Yam, and former Hong Kong politician Ted Hui, who fled the island and now lives in Adelaide, are among eight people wanted for alleged breaches under the controversial National Security Law.

title.children: China accuses Australia of 'flagrant slandering' as Hong Kong doubles down on arrest warrants for Australian residents

image.altText: A brown fluffy dog with some shaved fur being held on a rug

items.synopsis: Two dogs are put down after attacking two other dogs in Mount Gambier, with the owner of the attacking dogs agreeing to have them euthanased.

title.children: Dog owner 'very relieved' after pet recovers and attacking dogs put down

image.altText: A split image of actress Sarah Snook with fair skin and blond hair, and a view of the tree-lined Murray River from a cliff.

items.synopsis: South Australia's Hannah Kent is known globally for her novels. But when she began writing the script for Run Rabbit Run starring Sarah Snook, the landscape of Waikerie in her home state spoke to her.

title.children: How the striking beauty of SA's Riverland helped inspire Netflix thriller Run Rabbit Run

image.altText: A large construction site at a hospital in NSW.

items.synopsis: The ABC has been told the young man was crushed at about 9am. He was admitted to John Hunter Hospital, where the work was taking place, but did not survive.

title.children: 20-year-old dies after being crushed at NSW hospital construction site

image.altText: A composite of Ash Barty and her newborn baby.

items.synopsis: Former world number one tennis player Ash Barty announces the birth of her first child, Hayden.

title.children: 'Our beautiful boy': Australian tennis great Ash Barty gives birth to son

image.altText: A flat white drone with four rotors in flight with trees in the background.

items.synopsis: The Defence Department, police and border agents have grounded DJI drones over security concerns, but questioning from one senator has confirmed the devices are still used widely across government.

title.children: DJI drones in wide use across government departments despite defence, Border Force bans

image.altText: dog digging

items.synopsis: They're our furry, four-legged best friends, but dogs — like all pets — come with their challenges. We asked for your curly questions on canine ownership and you sent through hundreds. Here are some of the more common experiences, and our experts' advice.

title.children: You sent our experts hundreds of questions on dog behaviour. Here's what we learnt

image.altText: A yellow Ray White sign that says "lease" in front of a freestanding home.

items.synopsis: Australia's housing crisis continues as rents increase again over the June quarter. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Rents rise and there are fears of a recession if the RBA raises rates again, ASX loses ground

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has ended lower with banks among the sectors weighing on the market. Investors are worried that the Australian economy will be tipped into recession if the Reserve Bank keeps raising interest rates. Confidence was not helped by a slowdown in China's services and manufacturing industries last month. That news also weakened the Australian dollar. AMP fell 6.1 per cent as it faces a big compensation bill after former AMP financial advisers won a case against the investment house. Treasury Wine (-0.4 per cent) announced it would close its Karadoc winery in Victoria next year because of higher costs and lower sales. Bega Cheese rose 3.4 per cent today after taking a hit last month amid higher milk prices because of smaller herds and labour shortages on farms. Asian shares were also weaker amid tensions between China and the US after Beijing restricted exports of two chip making materials. Tonight attention turns to the Federal Reserve's latest minutes for clues on its next move on interest rates.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX ends in the red

children.content: The Australian share market has ended lower with banks among the sectors weighing on the market.
Investors are worried that the Australian economy will be tipped into recession if the Reserve Bank keeps raising interest rates.
Confidence was not helped by a slowdown in China's services and manufacturing industries last month.
That news also weakened the Australian dollar.
AMP fell 6.1 per cent as it faces a big compensation bill after former AMP financial advisers won a case against the investment house.
Treasury Wine (-0.4 per cent) announced it would close its Karadoc winery in Victoria next year because of higher costs and lower sales.
Bega Cheese rose 3.4 per cent today after taking a hit last month amid higher milk prices because of smaller herds and labour shortages on farms.
Asian shares were also weaker amid tensions between China and the US after Beijing restricted exports of two chip making materials.
Tonight attention turns to the Federal Reserve's latest minutes for clues on its next move on interest rates.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Moody's Investor Services expects the number of borrowers falling behind on their mortgage repayments to rise despite the RBA's pause in interest rate rises this month. The credit ratings agency says high interest rates and inflation will continue to push up mortgage delinquencies over the next 12 months. Analysts Helen Liu and Alena Chen say most at risk are borrowers who took out mortgages at very low interest rates. This includes the hundreds of thousands of borrowers on low fixed rate loans, who are facing much higher rates when their fixed term ends over the next year. Nearly half of home loans were fixed term by July 2021, compared to one fifth before 2020. Moody's says 1.26 per cent of home loans were at least 30 days in arrears over March, up from 1.05 per cent in December. But 4.04 per cent of riskier loans were behind in repayments in March. "The combination of high interest rates and inflation will continue to weaken mortgage borrowers' abilities to pay monthly home loan instalments," they said. "The fixed-rate period for a large number of mortgages will end over the next 6-12 months, which will add to home loan delinquencies." "However, Australia's unemployment rate is low (3.6 per cent in May), so we expect mortgage delinquencies will only rise moderately."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mortgage arrears expected to increase

children.content: Moody's Investor Services expects the number of borrowers falling behind on their mortgage repayments to rise despite the RBA's pause in interest rate rises this month.
The credit ratings agency says high interest rates and inflation will continue to push up mortgage delinquencies over the next 12 months.
Analysts Helen Liu and Alena Chen say most at risk are borrowers who took out mortgages at very low interest rates.
This includes the hundreds of thousands of borrowers on low fixed rate loans, who are facing much higher rates when their fixed term ends over the next year.
Nearly half of home loans were fixed term by July 2021, compared to one fifth before 2020.
Moody's says 1.26 per cent of home loans were at least 30 days in arrears over March, up from 1.05 per cent in December.
But 4.04 per cent of riskier loans were behind in repayments in March.
"The combination of high interest rates and inflation will continue to weaken mortgage borrowers' abilities to pay monthly home loan instalments," they said.
"The fixed-rate period for a large number of mortgages will end over the next 6-12 months, which will add to home loan delinquencies."
"However, Australia's unemployment rate is low (3.6 per cent in May), so we expect mortgage delinquencies will only rise moderately."

props.alt: graph showing mortgages in arrears by year

children.content: Home loan arrears
(Moody's)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wyloo Metals, which is owned by mining billionaire Andrew Forrest, is set to buy nickel miner Mincor Resources. The $750 million takeover will turn Wyloo into a major nickel producer with Mincor's Cassini nickel sulphide deposit in Kambalda in Western Australia's goldfields region. Wyloo now owns more than 90 per cent of Mincor, allowing it to buy the rest of the firm's shares. Nickel is used in the production of batteries for electric vehicles. Wyloo is looking at building a $1 billion battery materials processing plant with nickel miner IGO in Kwinana, south west of Perth. It's the latest acquisition in the renewable energy space for Mr Forrest. “Wyloo has targeted nickel sulphides as they are the greenest and cheapest option for battery manufacturing: they have the best economics, can be processed into battery grade nickel with the lowest environmental footprint and are fully recyclable,” Mr Forrest said. Wyloo chief executive Luca Giacovazzi said the company was also looking to increase spending on exploration in the Kambalda region. “The acquisition of Mincor turns Wyloo into a fully integrated nickel business that brings together high-grade nickel production from Kambalda with our planned downstream processing facility in Kwinana,” he said. “By adding Mincor to our portfolio, we’ve introduced a producing mine alongside our long-life development projects, with all our ore bodies located in the tier one jurisdictions of Australia and Canada.” Australia is seeking to build a critical minerals processing industry.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Andrew Forrest's nickel expansion

children.content: Wyloo Metals,
which is owned by mining billionaire Andrew Forrest, is set to buy nickel miner Mincor Resources.
The $750 million takeover will turn Wyloo into a major nickel producer with Mincor's Cassini nickel sulphide deposit in Kambalda in Western Australia's goldfields region.
Wyloo now owns more than 90 per cent of Mincor, allowing it to buy the rest of the firm's shares.
Nickel is used in the production of batteries for electric vehicles.
Wyloo is looking at building a $1 billion battery materials processing plant with nickel miner IGO in Kwinana, south west of Perth.
It's the latest acquisition in the renewable energy space for Mr Forrest.

“Wyloo has targeted nickel sulphides as they are the greenest and cheapest option for battery manufacturing: they have the best economics, can be processed into battery grade nickel with the lowest environmental footprint and are fully recyclable,” Mr Forrest said.
Wyloo chief executive Luca Giacovazzi said the company was also looking to increase spending on exploration in the Kambalda region.

“The acquisition of Mincor turns Wyloo into a fully integrated nickel business that brings together high-grade nickel production from Kambalda with our planned downstream processing facility in Kwinana,” he said.

“By adding Mincor to our portfolio, we’ve introduced a producing mine alongside our long-life development projects, with all our ore bodies located in the tier one jurisdictions of Australia and Canada.”
Australia is seeking to build a critical minerals processing industry.

image.altText: A woman walks on a road with rubble and damaged buildings on both sides of it.

image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

title.children: The simple reason why Australian mortgage borrowers are in more pain than those in other countries

image.altText: Jake sits in a chair while receiving treatment

title.children: Jake thought bowel cancer was an old person's disease — until he was diagnosed

image.altText: A woman smiles as her two small children sit at the top of a slide.

image.altText: An illustration of artists JK-47, Alex Lahey and Sarah Blasko

items.synopsis: More than 840 cover songs have been played in the triple j studios across 20 years. The data shows us how artists craft a cover song.

title.children: Some of the world's biggest songs are covers. What makes a good one?
